| image = Looking up the Tuckasegee.jpg image_size = image_alt = photograph of

| Carolina image_caption = View upriver from Old River Rd. above Bryson City

The 'Tuckasegee River' (variant spellings include 'Tuckaseegee' and
'Tuckaseigee') flows entirely within western North Carolina. It begins its
course in Jackson County above Cullowhee at the confluence of Panthertown and
Greenland creeks. It flows in a northwesterly direction into Swain County and
through the center of Bryson City, North Carolina. The river passes around the
Bryson City Island Park, where it then enters Fontana Lake and then the Little
Tennessee River.

The name Tuckasegee may be an anglicisation of the Cherokee word
daksiyiâ[takhÅ¡iyi] in the local Cherokee varietyââTurtle Place.â The river is
dotted with stone fishing weirs most easily viewed when water levels are
low. See Anne Frazier Rogers,
â[http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/sero/appalachian/sec6.htm Fish
weirs as part of the cultural landscape],â
[http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/sero/appalachian/contents.htm
Appalachian Cultural Resources Workshop Papers].
[http://www.panoramio.com/photo/17833650 Photo] of the Allman fish weir
discussed in the paper.

Fishing, hiking and paddling are among the recreational opportunities along
the river.
